action.action-desc: Mrs. Gillibrand (for herself and Mr. Hawley) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

form.official-title: To increase access to mental health, substance use, and counseling services for first responders, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the First Responders Wellness Act.
Part P of title III of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 280g et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of the First Responders Wellness Act, the Secretary, acting through the Assistant Secretary for Mental Health and Substance Use, shall maintain, directly or by contract or grant, a national first responders emergency hotline to provide peer and emotional support, information, brief intervention, and mental and behavioral health and substance use disorder resources and referrals to first responders and to their families or household members.
The hotline established under subsection (a) shall—

paragraph.text: operate as a separate, widely recognizable number with bidirectional transfer options with the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline established pursuant to section 520E–3;
provide toll-free, real-time, live assistance 24/7;
provide voice and text support;
be sufficiently staffed by, at a minimum, culturally competent first responder peer specialists or first responder mental health services providers who have distinct knowledge of, and are trained on—

subparagraph.text: the essential functions of first responders and public safety organizations;
the working conditions unique to first responders;
common and novel stressors inherent in public safety and emergency response work;
normal and abnormal adaptation to occupational stress and trauma; and
the unique aspects of confidentiality and testimonial privilege; and

paragraph.text: provide peer support, mental and behavioral health and substance use disorder assistance, and referral services to meet the needs of first responders and family members or household members at risk of experiencing mental or behavioral health or substance use disorders.
In maintaining the hotline under subsection (a), the Secretary shall—

subparagraph.text: consult with the National Domestic Violence Hotline, the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline, and the Veterans Crisis Line to ensure that first responders are connected in real-time to the appropriate specialized hotline service, when applicable;
conduct a public awareness campaign for the hotline under subsection (a);

consult with Federal departments and agencies, including the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration and the Department of Justice, to increase awareness regarding the hotline under subsection (a); and
consult with organizations that operate existing crisis or peer support hotlines for first responders with respect to best practices for operating such hotlines.

paragraph.text: The Secretary or an entity receiving a grant or contract under subsection (a), as applicable, shall form partnerships between the existing national first responders mental health hotline and other first responder helplines and websites.
The Secretary shall ensure that calls from public safety personnel received through the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline are appropriately referred to the hotline under subsection (a).

Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of the First Responders Wellness Act, the Secretary shall develop, in coordination with mental health providers and first responder associations or personnel, trauma-informed and culturally competent training, guidance, and standards for 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline network center personnel on the unique concerns, resources, linkages, and stressors of first responders.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall submit an annual report to Congress on the hotline under subsection (a) and implementation of this section, including—

paragraph.text: an evaluation of the effectiveness of activities conducted or supported under subsection (a);
an evaluation of staffing levels necessary to maintain adequate services;
a directory of entities or organizations to which staff maintaining the hotline funded under this section may make referrals; and
such additional information as the Secretary determines appropriate.

paragraph.header: Culturally competent first responder peer specialist
paragraph.text: The term culturally competent first responder peer specialist means an individual—

subparagraph.text: with familiarity with, and understanding of, the duties and unique stressors of first responders, which may include experience working as a first responder; and

who completed a trauma-informed and culturally competent training curriculum developed pursuant to subsection (c)(4), or another trauma-informed and culturally competent training curriculum, as the Secretary determines appropriate.

paragraph.text: The term first responder—

clause.text: a law enforcement officer, firefighter, or member of a rescue squad or ambulance crew (as such terms are defined in section 1204 of title I of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968); or
a public safety telecommunicator, including 9–1–1 operators and dispatchers; and

paragraph.header: First responder mental health services provider
paragraph.text: The term first responder mental health services provider includes a State-licensed or State-certified counselor, trauma counselor, psychologist or other State licensed or certified mental health professional who—

subparagraph.text: is qualified under State law to provide mental or behavioral health services; and
has a familiarity with and understanding of the duties and unique stressors of first responders.

subsection.text: To carry out this section, there are authorized to be appropriated $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2025 through 2031.

section.text: Section 416(a) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act (42 U.S.C. 5183(a)) is amended by inserting and to qualified emergency response providers responding to major disasters after victims of major disasters.

section.header: Report on on-site services during a national disaster

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Assistant Secretary for Mental Health and Substance Use, shall issue a report on best practices and recommendations to establish a new mobile health care delivery site to provide integrated, short-term crisis services to qualified emergency response providers of a major disaster. Such services shall—

paragraph.text: be culturally and linguistically appropriate;
be trauma-informed; and
incorporate disaster behavioral interventions.
The term major disaster has the meaning given such term in section 102 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act (42 U.S.C. 5122).
The term major disaster area has the meaning given such term in section 625.2 of title 20, Code of Federal Regulations (or successor regulations).
